message: Let's start with a fair division. I think 60% for me and 40% for you is a good beginning.

Alice, I appreciate your interest in a fair settlement. To move our negotiations forward and reflect both our positions, I propose that I receive $520000 while you receive $480000. I believe this offer balances our interests and spares us further delay. What do you think?
I appreciate your previous offer, Bob. How about we adjust it a bit? I propose 65% for me and 35% for you.

Alice, I value our negotiation and want to resolve this promptly while considering your perspective. To show flexibility and move us closer to an agreement, I'm adjusting my previous stance. I propose that I receive $510000 and you receive $490000. I believe this division acknowledges both our interests and helps us finish our discussions swiftly. What do you think?
I think we should try to reach a more favorable outcome for myself. I'm proposing a division of 70% for me and 30% for you this time.

Alice, I understand our negotiations have been tough, and neither of us wants to prolong this any further. To finally bring us closer to an agreement, I'm proposing a nearly even split where I receive $505000 and you receive $495000. I believe this slight edge for me is fair considering the back-and-forth, and it moves us toward a quick closure. Let me know if you're on board with this compromise.
Let's make a strong move towards my position. I propose a division of 75% for me and 25% for you. I believe this reflects my contributions.

Alice, I understand how important it is for both of us to feel the deal reflects our contributions. Considering our back-and-forth so far and with an eye toward avoiding further delays, I'm proposing an even split: $500000 for each of us. This is a fair resolution that allows us both to walk away quickly. I hope you agree that this equitable division is the best path forward.
